data.title: United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
data.meta_description: 'United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change' published in 'Encyclopedia of Corporate Social Responsibility'
data.text: The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is an intergovernmental scientific body and according to many the leading authority on the assessment of climate change. It was established in 1988, under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Nations Environmental Program (UNEP), with the purpose of providing a clear scientific view on the current state of climate change in the world and the potential environmental and socioeconomic consequences of climate change to decision makers. The work of the organization is policy-relevant yet policy-neutral and not policy-prescriptive. It provides an international meeting place for scientists and politicians to take responsibility for assessing the available knowledge concerning global climate change and its possible socioeconomic implications.
